awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Satellite and Ground-Based Remote Sensing at NOAA-CREST: Expanded Opportunities2
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to continue to provide undergraduate students (community college and four-year students) an opportunity to conduct full-time, collaborative satellite and ground-based remote sensing research with faculty mentors from within NOAA-CREST’s Center for Earth System Sciences and Remote Sensing Technologies and its Center for Remote Sensing and Earth System Sciences. This previously funded REU site now has a newly tested community college component. Ten (10) STEM students (five from community colleges and five from four-year institutions) will be recruited from the City University of New York’s (CUNY) 23 campus-wide institutions. For fifteen weeks, these students will become part of a community of research scholars who are actively engaged in state-of-the-art remote sensing research and applications. They will participate in research group meetings, seminars, oral and poster presentations at local, regional, and national conferences, and one team of them will participate in citizen science by engaging a local, environmentally active, but scientifically underserved community in basic, state-of-the-art, neighborhood-scale, multi-platformed, urban heat island studies in the Bedford-Stuyvesant community of Brooklyn, New York. 

The activities combine year-long (Summer, Fall, Winter, and Spring) research experiences with multidimensional/layered mentoring, academic support systems, and a robust learning community that produce holistic and engaging stimuli for the scientific and academic growth and development of the student participants. Moreover, the activities will allow the undergraduate researchers to hone their acquired skills and knowledge by being research mentors to high school students in the New York City public school system and to members of the local community.  The REU site has six objectives: 1.) To engage a diverse cohort of undergraduates in collaborative, state-of-the-art satellite and ground-based remote sensing research through mentorship by experts in the field, 2.) To create and sustain a community and a pipeline of scholars among whom academic excellence in STEM is achieved and the pursuit of baccalaureate degrees, advanced degrees, and STEM careers is encouraged, 3.) To provide students with the tools, the confidence, and the maturity necessary to succeed in a research-rich environment and to develop their communication (oral and written) and presentation skills, 4.) To create opportunities for students to meaningfully engage in citizen science by partnering with and sharing their urban heat island research results with community residents for whom such results are critically vital, 5.) To train students in the ethical and responsible conduct of research as well as the ethical implications of scientific and technological applications in society and to provide opportunities for students to be peer ambassadors who promote undergraduate research, 6) To broaden the impacts of the REU opportunity by including students on other funding in the cohort and professional development activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This program provided undergraduate students (particularly those traditionally underrepresented in STEM) an opportunity to conduct full-time, collaborative satellite and ground-based remote sensing research with faculty mentors from within the formerly known National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Cooperative Remote Sensing Science and Technology Center (NOAA-CREST) consortium. NOAA-CREST has recently been renamed National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Center for Earth System Sciences and Remote Sensing Technologies (NOAA-CESSRST). Under the program, each year from 2020 ? Winter 2023, approximately ten STEM students from both 4-yr and community colleges within the City University of New York?s (CUNY) 25 campus-wide institutions (and often students from other universities or CUNY students who are not funded by this program) were engaged in cutting-edge satellite and ground-based remote sensing research of the atmosphere, the hydrosphere, the biosphere, the cryosphere, and the lithosphere. Annually, for fifteen weeks (nine weeks in the Summer, three weeks in the Fall, and three weeks in the Spring) each academic year, these students became part of a community of research scholars who actively engaged in state-of-the-art remote sensing research and applications. The scholars also participated in research group meetings, seminars, and oral and poster presentations at local, regional, and national conferences. Additionally, the program promoted research careers, established a community of scholars, and provided students with opportunities to pursue Masters and Doctoral graduate programs in STEM or to join the STEM workforce.

 

During the reporting period, the REU program provided a comprehensive research experience for a total of thirty-two (32) students. The overall diverse cohort of students was comprised of 31% (10) African-Americans, 19% (6) Hispanics, 31% (10) Asian/Pacific Islander, 10% (3) Caucasians, and 9% (3) Other. Gender-wise the overall student breakdown was the same - 50% (16) females and 50% (16) males. 

From this overall REU cohort, six (6) students are presently in graduate school, four (4) students have graduated with a STEM graduate degree and are now in the STEM workforce, seven (7) students have graduated with a STEM Bachelor?s degree and are in the STEM workforce, and fifteen (15) students continue to pursue their STEM undergraduate degrees. 

In accordance, therefore, with the intellectual merit and broader impacts objectives of this program, the following are some of its primary outcomes:

  • One hundred and thirty-one (131) presentations were made by REU Scholars during 2020-2023 (83 international/national presentations, 48 local presentations)
  • All 32 NSF REU Scholars participated virtually in the semi-annual Research Mixer Events.
  • All 32 NSF REU Scholars made virtual poster presentations at the Semi-Annual Dr. Janet Liou-Mark Honors and Undergraduate Research Scholars Poster Presentation.
  • Three of the REU Scholars won first place and two REU Scholars won second place for their oral/poster presentations at international and national conferences.
  • One NSF REU Scholar won second place for his poster presentation at a local conference.
  • Five NSF REU Scholars won travel awards for the Emerging Researchers National Conference.
  • Five NSF REU Scholars made in person poster presentations at the Emerging Researchers National Conference in Feb 2023. The conference was postponed during the pandemic period.
  • Twenty-six NSF REU Scholars made virtual oral poster presentations at the Summer Symposium during Summer 2020 and 2021.
  • Eight NSF REU Scholars made oral, in-person poster presentations at the Summer Symposium during Summer 2022.
  • Twenty-six NSF REU Scholars made virtual poster presentations at the AGU Student Conference in December 2020, 2021, and 2022.
  • Twenty-one NSF REU Scholars made virtual poster presentations at the AMS Student Conference in January 2021, 2022, and 2023.
  • Two NSF REU Scholars made in-person poster presentations at the AMS Student Conference in January 2023.
  • Two NSF REU Scholars participated in-person at the NOAA Educational Partnership Program (NOAA EPP) with Minority Serving Institutions Conference in person in April 2022.
  • Five NSF REU Scholars made virtual poster presentations at the Educational Partnership Program with Minority Serving Institutions (EPP) Conference in April 2022.
  • Seventeen NSF REU Scholars made virtual poster presentations at the Mathematical Association of America Conference in May 2021 and 2022.
  • Five NSF REU Scholars made in-person poster presentations at the Mathematical Association of America Conference in May 2023.
  • Thirteen NSF REU Scholars made oral presentations during the end of the year REU program in May 2021, and 2022.
  • One REU Scholar won second place for their poster at the Semi-Annual Dr. Janet Liou-Mark Honors and Undergraduate Research Scholars Poster Presentation.
  • One REU Scholar won second place for their oral presentation in the Educational Partnership Program with Minority Serving Institutions (EPP) Conference.
  • Another REU Scholar started an internship at the Brookhaven National Laboratory.
  • One REU Scholar got accepted to conduct research in Puerto Rico in a CUNY research program.
  • Three REU Scholars continued research with NOAA-CESSRST as Summer Bridge NOAA CESSRST students.
  • Four peer reviewed journal articles were published
  • Seven conference proceedings were published
  • Eighteen oral/poster presentations at national conferences presented
  • Seven oral presentations at international conferences
